tool.name: FlashLFQ
tool.description: Ultra-fast label-free quantification algorithm for mass-spectrometry proteomics

filelist.name: psm-file
filelist.label: Select PSM file
filelist.help: Add your identification file here. Accepted file formats are Morpheus .tsv, MaxQuant msms.txt, PeptideShaker .tabular, or generic .txt/.tsv.

select.name: raw-type
select.label: Select the type of your spectra file
select.help: All formats others than mzML will be converted to mzML before processing.

filelist.name: expdesign
filelist.label: Select ExperimentalDesign.tsv file
filelist.help: Add an extra file that contains the experimental design. It must contain, for each file, its Condition name, sample ID, fraction ID and replicate ID.
filelist.url_label: See the documentation for explanations and examples

number.name: ppm
number.label: PPM Tolerance
number.help: The mass tolerance in parts per million for both MS/MS-identified species and match-between-runs.

checkbox.name: mbr
checkbox.label: Peptide identity propagation (Match Between Runs)
checkbox.help: Maps MS/MS identifications from one run onto other runs in which they were not identified, using retention time and isotopic envelope similarity.

number.name: pipfdr
number.label: PIP FDR Cutoff
number.help: The false discovery rate threashold for reported PIP events.

checkbox.name: rmc
checkbox.label: Require MS/MS Identification in Condition
checkbox.help: Only try to match peptides from proteins if an MS/MS identified peptide from that protein was observed in the condition.

number.name: mrt
number.label: Maximum MBR window (minutes)
number.help: The retention-time error allowed in match-between runs. This is not the systematic time shift, but a sort of "variance" or "error" in the retention time allowed.

checkbox.name: nor
checkbox.label: Normalize intensities
checkbox.help: Corrects systematic intensity errors with median normalization. The main assumption is that most proteins do not change in abundance between samples.

checkbox.name: usepepq
checkbox.label: Use PEP Q Values
checkbox.help: Determines how FlashLFQ chooses which peptides to quantify (only applies to MetaMorpheus identifications). Using PEP Q generally yields more peptide IDs.

checkbox.name: sha
checkbox.label: Use shared peptides for protein quantification
checkbox.help: Uses peptide sequences shared between proteins for protein quantification.

checkbox.name: bay
checkbox.label: Bayesian Protein Fold-Change Analysis
checkbox.help: This estimates each protein's fold-change relative to the control condition using Bayesian statistics. Also calculates posterior error probability (PEP) and false discovery rate (FDR).

string.name: ctr
string.label: Control Condition
string.help: The condition to calculate protein fold-changes relative to.

number.name: fcc
number.label: Log2 Fold-change cutoff
number.help: The protein log2-transformed fold-change that is considered to be not important, or background.

number.name: mcm
number.label: MCMC iterations
number.help: The number of iterations to perform for the Markov-Chain Monte Carlo sampler in the Bayesian stats engine. A larger number of iterations will result in a slower but more precise estimate of the protein fold-change, the PEP, and the FDR.

number.name: rns
number.label: MCMC random seed
number.help: The seed for the random number generator in the Markov-Chain Monte Carlo sampler. You should probably not change this unless unless you are trying to reproduce an analysis.

checkbox.name: int
checkbox.label: Integrate Peak Areas
checkbox.help: By default, FlashLFQ reports the peak height and not peak area. Enabling integration reports the peak area.

checkbox.name: chg
checkbox.label: Only quantify identified charge
checkbox.help: FlashLFQ will only quantify the identified charge, and will not look for alternative charges.

number.name: iso
number.label: Isotope PPM Tolerance
number.help: The mass tolerance in parts per million of isotope peaks (e.g., M+1, M+2 peaks).

number.name: nis
number.label: Number of isotopes required
number.help: The number of isotopic peaks required to detect an isotopic envelope.
